description.text:
First Drone Project - LEAF

This is a prototype of a safe flying machine made in FabLab Rutech.
I created this drone to meet the growing need of young people. The latter are very interested to learn and play with the drones but they are afraid of the broken ones. That's why I created a drone with a shape that allows it to withstand the uncertain piloting of the child. He takes time to learn, while having fun and without taking risks for himself and for others.

Design level, this drone is simple and futuristic. I called it LEAF, because without even stolen it, I knew that this drone would have a flying aspect of an autumn leaf that in with the wind. Moreover, I wanted to give a soul to this drone. I drew her lungs. When the blades rotate, the drone breathes and comes alive!

UPDATE

  • 13/09/2016 Uploading .dxf files [Bottom & Top]
    Adding some informations

  • 27/09/2017 Uploading Carbon Frame pictures

  • 28/09/2017 Uploading SolidWorks Top File

• FC : Naze32 Cleanflight
  • Motors : 4x EMAX2204 2300KV Brushless
  • ESC : 4x 20A BLHeli OneShot
  • Battery : 3S 1500 mAh 25C

• Laser Cut : ARKETYPE 100 W
  • Bottom & Plate : Medium 3mm
  • Total weight with battery : 432g
  • Total weight w/o : 327g

  • Carbon Frame 150g all

  • PLA Frame made by 3D Printer :
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PSs51U7xKHc
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iAG5v_oYjDI

[FOLLOW ME]
Instagram : eih3prog

description.text: This is a roof drain screen to keep large debris out of downspouts. Our flat roof has several 1.5 inch openings around the edge which let rainwater drain off the roof. If these openings get clogged with leaves or other large debris, we end up with a miniature lake above our heads. None of the commercial drain screens fit or work well, so I designed this to protect our roof. Note that I haven't tested these drains on the roof yet; check back in a couple weeks to hear if they work. No warranty given that these will actually protect your roof. Caveat downloader. More details at http://makerbot216.blogspot.com/2010/02/making-practical-things.html

1) Print out several copies.
2) Clean off extra filaments from the print head travelling between the legs.
3) Paint, either to protect from UV or to ensure no one steps on one of the screens.
4) Get ladder, and place against house.
5) Climb onto roof. (Be careful!)
6) Insert one screen in each drain, with the two legs fitting into the drain to hold it steady. Make sure the screen sits mostly flush on the roof's surface.
7) Climb off the roof. (Be doubly careful!)
8) Drink beer, and enjoy not worrying about whether the drains are clogged. Update, 2/27/10: One screen has been on the roof during the recent storms, and did well - there's little (small) debris clogging the screen, but it's keeping the seed pods out of the drain. I found the springy arms broke very easily because of the small cross-section and less strength between layers. I ended up removing the legs, drilling a pair of 1/8" holes in the top, and placing a U-shaped piece of #14 gauge wire into the holes to keep the screen centered over the hole and in place. There's now four in place on our roof, with another six needed.

description.text:
Rev. 1, with fixed dimensions, according to 3D model of the phone http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764862

Bike mount for the Oneplus Two cell phone.

Both parts are locked in place via a zip tie connecting them together.
The parts can be printed lying on their side, for maximum strength and simplicity (very little support material is needed in this way).

Attempts at removing from the bike a previous version of this mount led to a lengthy fight, so I would definitely trust this contraption to hold my phone in place!

Lateral_holder and Longitudinal_holder files pair:

Fits the stem of my dreary mountain bike.

Lateral_holder_33x34 and Longitudinal_holder_33x34 files pair:

Fits the stem of my racing bike (FSA 0S-99, elliptical cross-section, dimensions: 32.57mm width, 34.1mm height).

Notes:

description.text:
These are 3D tokens for the Decktet card game.

What is Decktet ?

The Decktet is a 45-card deck of cards in 6 suits.

The core of the Decktet is the 36-card basic deck. Each suit has 10 cards, a thing accomplished by most of the cards being double-suited. Most of the cards also have a name and illustration. The Decktet is a game system released under an open license.

There are also 9 extended deck cards. Like Jokers in a traditional deck of cards, they are used in some games but not in others.

The Decktet is available in a free print-and-play version. There are also printed decks available for purchase.

There are dozens of different games that can be played with the Decktet

More info about Decktet :

  • http://www.decktet.com/
  • https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/37301/decktet

What about those tokens ?

Many games uses tokens to represent resources or attribution. I made the tokens so they follow the six different suits of the game (sun, moon, wave, leaf, knots, wyrm) with six different symbole in six different colors.

You can choose the color you want (considering what are you possibilities :p)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

100

Notes:

The token have a diameter of 23.2 mm and a depth of 2.3mm (and are such fully functional for french supermarket cart :p)

The symbol were drawn in Inkscape based of the official suits symbols then converted to Openscad using Dan Newman wonderful plug-in.

Then I merged the SCAD generated with a basic round token and tadah !

You can find the SVG source, the SCAD source and the STL, so please be free to customize those tokens to you liking !

Watch: https://youtu.be/XOadJcszKYQ
For more information : https://brico3d.blogspot.com/

description.text: This derivate of the greg's carriage allows you to remove/change/insert the extruder just by pushing or pulling the little lever in front of it. Here you can see how it works: http://youtu.be/I2rSAMgzOOQ By pushing the lever the plate moves by less than a millimeter, but just enough to make pressure on the screws and hold them down. UPDATE: I published another version of the lever, wich can apply a bit more pressure.

In addition to the classic greg's carriage vitamins (zip-ties, screws for the belt holder and tightener, nuts) you will need 4 M3 screws (mine are 15 mm), washers and nuts. -print the desired carriage (1/2/no fans) and all the other parts
-insert 3 M3 screws in the holes, from the bottom of the carriage
-clamp the carriage to the linera bearings, and apply the zip ties
-prepare the lever attached to the "plate" part (someone have a better name to suggest for this part? )
-put the plate on the carriage and the cover in the screws. apply washers and nuts If you want to clean the extruder attachment holes be careful to pull the lever before! In your extruder you should have the 2 m4 screws firmly locked, so they won't come off when you insert them into the holes. maybe some glue will do it, in my case i used two nuts and modified the hot-end mount to make space for them. (if anybody needs it it's a modified budashnozzle 1.0 mount, just ask and i'll publish it..)

description.text:
2 Simple 24pin combs with the Swerigs logotype.

What's "Swerigs"?
Swerigs is a group for people interested in computers and technology and is mostly aimed for Swedish people and Swedish-talking people. The group is made for people to discuss, post pictures, get feedback and ideas, share experiences etc.

Read more here: http://swerigs.com/

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1q-PSOeiELSSjBA_WbysfOKLwpI__PMt3v8icWTcQzOg/edit

Geek wedding? Want to count the tables in hexadecimal? The files include the freeCAD source files, so you can do more than the numbers 0-9 that are provided out of the box.

title: Medicine Cabinet Shelf
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My wife and I bought a little shelf by OXO that is designed to go into a medicine cabinet. The idea of the shelf is it allows you to store smaller items inside your medicine cabinet without wasting the whole shelf. Think of it like a half length self.

The problem we ran into is OXO stopped selling it on their website. I figured since I have a 3D printer I would print one out.

The whole thing is 5 1/8" tall (131mm), 6 3/8" wide (161.6mm) and 3 1/4" deep (82.7mm). I printed mine laying down with the curved top portion facing my cooling fans.

The nail file holder is one of my other creations:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1760758

Filament is Just PLA's turquoise:
https://www.justpla.com/turquoise-play175-1kg?search=PLAY175TRQ-1KG

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

10%

Notes:

I printed mine laying down with the curved top portions facing the cooling fan to keep them from sagging.
With how mine printed out all I had to do was place in medicine cabinet and enjoy the extra room.
I designed this by using Tinkercad and the existing OXO medicine cabinet shelf

description.text: This is a dual extrusion Deadpool coaster. Just add both files and print. Infill won't make much difference as they're thin like a regular coaster. I printed at .15mm layer height. I have also included the factory file for anyone using Simplify3D. I have added a tool change script to try to stop color bleeding.

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30

Notes:

For anyone using the flashforge creator pro and simplify3d, I use the following script to get much cleaner prints. Adds more time as it lets one side cool down upon tool change, but it's worth it. I printed in abs, so if you're printing in PLA you will have to adjust the temps.... Just go to process settings, scripts, tool change script and copy the following.

; Tool chance script start
G1 X120 Y-70 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp.
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S160 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S230 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S160 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S230 T1; Heat active extruder to 230c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; Tool chance script end

I dont see the left extruder being told what temp to work at as both the base and color process only specify temps for the right extruder only. I tried printing anyway it seem to work except the tool change unloads the left extruder and when it goes to print there's nothing.

description.text:

This is a dual extrusion Flash coaster. Just add both files and print. Infill won't make much difference as they're thin like a regular coaster. I printed at .15mm layer height. I have also included the factory file for anyone using Simplify3D. I have added a tool change script to try to stop color bleeding

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30

Notes:

For anyone using the flashforge creator pro and simplify3d, I use the following script to get much cleaner prints. Adds more time as it lets one side cool down upon tool change, but it's worth it. I printed in abs, so if you're printing in PLA you will have to adjust the temps.... Just go to process settings, scripts, tool change script and copy the following.

; Tool chance script start
G1 X120 Y-70 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp.
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S160 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S230 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S160 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S230 T1; Heat active extruder to 230c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; Tool chance script end

description.text:
This is just the raw sketchup file I used to make the lamp shown here. In the end, I was displeased with the result as a whole and thus abandoned it.

It was a mostly based off of adafruit's neopixel camera light ring here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:235242

I had too many problems with the light being an inconsistent color and with faulty leds. They would start doing strange things when brought up to their full power (like defaulting to a red like color, or just not responding). Also, it tended to make extremely harsh shadows due to the straight angle. I opted to go with a non-rgb led lighting solution where I could bounce and diffuse the light instead.

Use at your own risk. The stl's included are not complete. You would have to reexport the pieces needed from the sketchup file

This is a custom 3D printed magazine well that is designed to work with all nerf magazines. It features a release button like most nerf blasters which allows for easier release.

Its purpose is for crazy nerf modifications. For example: A homemade nerf blaster, a blaster with multiple magwells, a cheap strayven option. There are many more possibilities.

Note: This hasn't been tested with the 25/18 round drums, 10 round straight magazine or 15 round curved magazine as I don't have any. If you do, please let me know if it isn't compatible.
The internal pivot of the release may also require a little filing after printing.

title: WWII 2.36" Bazooka Rocket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These files allow you to create replica of a WWII 2.36" Bazooka rocket. The files consist of two parts for the head and one part for the tail assembly. I used a piece of 1" PVC for the tube between the head and tail assembly. I found the PVC to be a better solution than printing the tube as it needs no finishing if you plan finish out the rough 3D printed surface. 1" is the inside diameter of the PVC tube. The outside diamter is about 1.3". The outside diamter of the original Bazooka tube is about 1.25" so the PVC is close enough on my opinion.

The length of the tube between the head and tail is 7.5". You will need to add a little extra to the 7.5" to insert into the head and tail assemblies for gluing. I would suggest printing the head and tail parts first then measure how much needs to be inserted into those parts and add that amount to 7.5".

The photo shows an assembled model (left) that was printed with PLA filament. The model has bee primered in preparation for painting. The rocket on the right is the original WWII practice round used for measurements.

WIth little or no finishout (besides painting) this model could pass the 10 foot rule for resemblance to the original. Spending some time sanding and filling will give you a prop that is very close to the now very expensive original examples. I intend to use these to fill replica shipping crates to go along with a WWII living history display.

Instructions

  1. Print head pieces and tail assembly
  2. Using two part epoxy, glue two head pieces together
  3. Measure distance you will insert the PVC pipe into the tail assembly and head and add this amounto to 7.5"
  4. Cut 1" PVC to length caclulated above (1" PVC has about a 1.3" outside diameter).
  5. Test fit the PVC into the tail and head assemblies. It may be necessary to do some sanding on the ends of the PVC or inside the assembly to get them to go together. I found one type of plastic slid in with no sanding and another required sanding.
  6. Once you determine the parts fit well, join them permantly with two part epoxy leaving 7.5" of tube between the two assemblies.
  7. At this point you can sand and/or use filler to smooth out the surfaces until you get the smoothness you are happy with. The original rockets had a perfectly smooth surface so you may want to finish your replica out before painting.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator (makerbot clone)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20 layer height

Infill:

10%
I used a digital caliper to take measurements from an original WWII example then created the model using Sketchup.

comments.author: WMalloy5

comments.text: The overall length of my original example is 21.5".  The PVC length will depend on how much you insert into the head.  I just cut mine several inches longer than needed then coated it with epoxy and slipped the head down the tube until the length was 21.5". Inserting more pvc into the head will help keep the head straight while the epoxy cures. Also pay attention the fins while attaching to the PVC. There is very little room for the PVC in the fins and it is easy to get them set crooked.

title: Apollonian Sphere Packing or Soddy Spheres

description.text:
Apollonion Sphere Packing is a recursive algorithm to fill a (hollow) ball with spheres of different diameters. No spheres are intersecting, they touch each other. At infinity there is no empty space inside the ball. The algorithm starts with four balls at the vertices of a tetrahedron.

This thing includes five stages of the Apollonion Sphere Packing. The number of spheres includes a circumscribing sphere (which is obviously not contained in the STL-file).
Soddy0_5.stl: 9 spheres
Soddy0_4.stl: 21 spheres
Soddy0_3.stl: 45 spheres
Soddy0_2.stl: 82 spheres
Soddy0_15.stl: 224 spheres
Soddy0_1.stl: 550 spheres
Soddy0_05.stl: 2922 spheres
(The number refers to the radius of the smallest spheres occurring in the file.)

To make it easier to print the packed spheres most STL-files has a halved version. One can print this twice and glue both sides to each other. Caution: please look carefully what is the right orientation before glueing.

Note: Although Soddy Spheres are non-intersecting, in the STL-files there is a small overlap. It is handy when the spheres are connected after printing ;-)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Creating Soddy Spheres

For the mathematics behind the Soddy Spheres, I refer to http://mathworld.wolfram.com/TangentSpheres.html or http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.127.4067&rep=rep1&type=pdf or http://paulbourke.net/fractals/apollony/

I created a C++ program to efficiently find all the spheres upto about 145,000 for the most dense packing. The output is then exported to openscad and converted to STL. (Although the most dense packing was too much for openscad.)

The algorithm starts with four spheres with radius 1 at the vertices of a tetrahedron, i.e. at
[1, 0, -sqrt(1/2)]
[-1, 0, -sqrt(1/2)]
[0, 1, sqrt(1/2)]
[0, -1, sqrt(1/2)]
which are circumscribed by a centered sphere with radius 1 / (1 + sqrt(6) / 2).
Then by an iterative procedure quadruplets of spheres are selected, the two touching spheres are computed and added to the collection.

Notes:

I used 50% infill because of the self tapping mounting screws that hold the mount to the block.

My mounting strategy

In my PA28-180 I chose to put the mount on the floor under the pilots seat as far forward as possible. I used high grip Velcro hooks on the bottom of the block to grab the rug under the seat. I also put an adjustable strap across the top of the unit, hooking the outer edges of the seat rails and pulling the unit down tight.

Don't over tighten the self tapping screws in the block, just turn until the mount is snug against the block.

title: Printrbot Play Wrap around 360 fan mount V2

description.text: This is an update to the other printrbot play fan mount i made earlier. This one provides airflow from all directions. I designed this to accommodate larger fans. I am using a 40x40x20mm part cooling fan and a 30x30x15mm hot end cooling fan. It mounts to tapped holes in the bottom of the extruder with three M3 screws. I used extra 6mm button head ones that came in my kit. To attach the fans, I used some craft wire and twisted the ends. You can also drill out the holes and use nuts and bolts if you want. I can now print beautiful 20 degree overhangs. 15 degree overhangs don't look too bad either. The ribbing prevents rotating air from coming out of the nozzle at an angle. Ducting to the hot end heat sink optimizes the air coming from the fan. An increased airflow fan here doesn't really make any difference.

title: Single Gang Decora Project Box

description.text:
** UNTESTED

This is a prototype design of a project box that will fit in an electrical wall box with a decora wall plate. It's a remix of jasonrobertfox's 12v decora plate adapter, but I have also included a couple of other things in the remix source list just because I used them for references. The wall plate and electrical box are unmodified, and just added to my project for reference. I've designed it based on some information I've found online for sizes of existing switches/plugs/boxes, but there are many different designs of electrical boxes; metal, abs plastic, some have extra pieces of plastic inside that others don't. If you can give me measurements that you need or tell me what about the box doesn't fit into your wall box, perhaps I can modify this design to be more compatible. I do not have a 3D printer to test it myself. At some point I will upload the design to a printing web site and purchase one. In the mean time, if anyone with a printer of their own tests this design out, please let me know what your results are.

Hello again...

Today I want to introduce almost a model of Renault FT 17 tank. I said "almost", because of 3D printing limitations and my laziness ( :) ) design has been simplified, but... it still looks like Renault FT.
Model has functional tracks. Model has movable turret and gun. If You want and know how You can motorize it... Or paint It like me and put it on the shelf.

To make it You need printed parts, glue and steel, carbon or even wood rod d=2,5mm (about 22 cm) for axles and gun and a few nuts and bolts (M3).
The best instruction are pics above (numbers are stl files names).
To make trucks You need 8 sets of "26.stl" (one side need 38 links). The links are connected by wire d=0,7mm. I use copper wire with d=0,7mm. It fits perfectly.

Traditionally SketchUp file included if You want to make some tuning or remix it.

Have fun...

description.text:
This is my first print that I made from beginning to end. I took measurements from a toy robot that my sister has (Julian CubeBot) and recreated it in SketchUp. Companion dog
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1767520

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

30

Notes:

I would recommend printing the Chest, Feet, Pelvis with infill and do the other parts without, but it wouldn't hurt anything to do it all with infill

Requirements

1/6" drill bit (preferably one with a hex shank)
Elastic cord (1.2 mm)
Needle with a large eye
Pliers

Step 1

Use the 1/6" drill bit and clean out the "tunnels" in preparation for the elastic cord. This is where that hex shank comes in handy. I did not attach the drill bit to my drill, I simply twisted the drill bit by hand into the pieces. Worked like a charm.

Step 2

Thread the Elastic cord through the "tunnels" of the robot. Tie a knot in one end, pull the elastic as tight as you can without breaking it, and tie a knot in the other end. There should be 4 pieces of elastic: 2 for the feet, legs and into the pelvis, 1 for the hand,arm, into the chest though the other arm and ending in the hand, 1 through head, chest and into the pelvis. Feeding the elastic through the "tunnels" was tough. What worked for me was threading the elastic into a fat needle, pushing the needle through the piece, and pulling it through with a pair of pliers.

Snap-on guard to prevent filament from getting tangled in the Z-rod.
Has a generous hole to allow some skewing if your rods are not completely straight. Since the hole passes all the way though, it is easy to align the guard to make sure it doesn't actually touch the rods. This also makes it possible to apply lubrication without removing the guard

Update 2016-09-13
Version 2. Stronger frame grip, will not break as easily as version 1. Less travel restriction in Z-axis. Widened guard for skewed Z-rods.

Update 2016-09-27
Version 3. Fits more snugly (0.25mm difference from v2). Will not move from printer vibrations.

description.text: Cold air intake for datsun 240z or any 240-260z with non flapper orange air filter housing. Take the cabin air vent out and cover the hole going under fender, put the printed sections on the air intake "horn", through the hole where the vent was, and the rings in between two sections should be spaced slightly to articulate and covered in duct tape. No guarantees- I've had it installed on my late 74 260z with a 71 orange air filter housing for 4 months now. I'd recommend printing in ABS as PLA might sag with under hood temps. It may work on a flapper filter housing- I don't have one to test it on.

title: Shower hook for sliding glass door V4 var angle

description.text:
This is a remix of Shower Hook for sliding glass door by Drelen.
This shower hook is a great idea. I printed it out, but my shower door top is different than the author's.

If you print this, please post a picture on the 'I've made one'. Thanks!

I went thru a couple of different remixes before getting it just right.
Using Freecad to remix this, I copied the pattern as exactly as possible then started modifying.

Changes made:

  1. Extend the support arm as my top is taller.
  2. Angled the support arm and hook arm inward as the sides of the shower top are not vertical.
  3. Added a little hook on the support arm, to catch the bottom lip to securely lock it in place.

Files:

I have included the freecad file, so those so inclined may modify the arm lengths, angles or whatever as they so choose.

title: cd rom stepper motor linear rail system

description.text:
DIY cd rom stepper motor linear rail
First off, a huge shout out and thanks to Mr Darwin for his great idea on using mouldable epoxy for the lead screw bolt. Please have a look at his YouTube channel for lots of great idea's and his projects.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC71gzWGsJ4ezSkm-Fnn9RHw

Things you will need besides a printer and filament lol.
1:) Hand mouldable Epoxy putty stick.
2:) Paper clip.
3:) Cd rom or DVD rom stepper motor.
4:) 3mm rod ( Found with stepper motor in Cd rom.)

Make a little ball of Mouldable Epoxy and press in the cup of slider nut, scrape off any over flow, align center of cup with at least two threads of the lead screw and lightly press down to form lead screw ridges in the epoxy, remove slider nut and let epoxy to set. Clean threads if needed

Unfold paper clip and cut 10 to 12 mm length and straiten best as possible. assemble the linear rail, and push the paper clip under the lead screw and into the hole in the slider nut.
Paper clip wire is to hold tension between the slide nut and lead screw.

Wire stepper and let your imagination Spark.

Their are two versions of the slider nut, one has the 3mm shaft size slightly bigger depending on your printer tolerance.

If you need mounting points feel free to ask .

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

As u wish

Notes:

Slide nut should be printed at 100% infill

comments.text: what do you mean ? A way to attach it to something ? or a printed thread?
comments.author: tecdroid

comments.text: I mean the slider nut. you use epoxy for it. why not just printing it?
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: The lead screw threads are too small to properly print, I tried more then once. I event went as far as to heat the lead screw and try melting the threads on printed parts, A resin printer would be able to pull it off im sure, but most of us don't have one. This way works Finally loll, and another plus side to using the Epoxy putty, is that, not all lead screws found in recycled cd or dvd roms are exactly the same thread patterns. I took apart 15 or so cd roms and thus far have 4 sets of different threads, So the molding process makes it a one part fits all so to speak. hope that answers it for you , If you make something with them or need to have the nut modified to attach to something, feel free to ask. the nut slider is very basic and my goal was to keep same base and add to it for projects needs.

description.text:
The best spin tops have a tip made of a very hard material in order to minimize friction between the top and the spin surface. This design requires a steel ball to be glued into the bottom of the print. One design uses 1/4 inch stainless steel ball bearings and the other 3/8 inch (Amazon has them). By using these and a concave glass lens or mirror surface, you can get spin times over 6 minutes.

Here's a short video showing the top in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lySgPi_sKsk

Add the Steel Ball

Clean up the print and then use super glue to hold the ball bearing in place.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

Using Fusion 360, I designed the cross section in 2D and then rotated it about the vertical axis using the Revolve command. I exported the STL file and then prepared it for printing with Simplify3D.

Hi, my name is Mckay Moore. I hate when my headphones decide to invent new untieable knots in my pocket. I was getting rather mad, and channelled that frustration into this. Enjoy!

To Use:

  1. Insert the headphone jack through center of the print and pull it all the way through until the buds meet with the edge of the print.

  2. Wrap the headphone cord around the print until you have about one wrap length till the jack is flush with the print.

  3. Locate the last wrapping and pass the audio jack though, traveling to the end opposite of the buds.

  4. Pass the jack though the end containing the buds, and enjoy compact tangle-free headphones!

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another implementation of letters-on-spikes, but contrasting in several points:

  • good customisability
  • Stronger joints. Those use my joints lib http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764043
  • Decent, symmetrical peg points for smooth ground penetration action

Finding a visually pleasing font which is available on thingiverse is still a challenge. None of those tentatively specified appear to be available. I've settled for three Google fonts "Lobster", "Pacifico" and "Chewy" now.
The font I use mostly for these signs is http://www.dafont.com/chinacat.font, regular type, which can be set to make the letters touch slightly without merging into each other a lot, which gives a good balance between mechanical stability and readability. It also has a less austere look to generated text then the more edgy defaultish and commonish alternatives.
Another font I like for this application is http://www.dafont.com/fennario.font, especially if a capital G is involved - chinacat capital G can easily be mistaken for a C, as can be seen in this example: http://www.dafont.com/chinacat.font?text=Gurken&psize=l - Fennario capital G features a much more distinct horizontal stroke: http://www.dafont.com/fennario.font?text=Gurken&psize=l
I'd like to hear about which fonts you favour for this item, as I would like to take a look at them myself.

description.text:
No conseguí fundas para mi telefono, así que diseñe la propia en Onshape. Había encontrado un par aquí en thingiverse, pero ninguna parecía coincidir correctamente todos los orificios, o no ajustaba correctamente. Este es el resultado de 4 etapas de re diseño. Icluyo los archivos con los exágonos, y uno plano. Recomiendo los exágonos pues sin ellos el teléfono se siente algo tibio.

Atención! está diseñado con tolerancia 0. Para imprimir, hay que probar con escalas que se correspondan con vuestros filamentos. Yo imprimí el mio en PLA, y lo escalé al 101%. Debí haber subido un poquitín mas. Quizás con el 102% ya quedaría perfecto.

Mi intensión es hacer un par de diseños más. Como para varias el aspecto del móbil un poco. Si tienen sujerencias, estoy abierto a ellas.

Sientanse libres de modificarlos y utilizarlos de forma no comercial.

I was looking for a case for my redmi note 3 pro, but found that they where expensive, and ugly. A friend of mine have the same phone, with an snap fit case and I thougth i could design something similar for my 3d printer.
I'ts modeled on Onshape. There's another case in thingiverse, but the holes didnt cuite match mine's and cudn't fit it correctly. So, I've found myself going trougt 4 iterations of designs, prints and revisions, to get to this last design.

I've uploaded a plain one, and another with a design of hexagons, incase that you dont like it. I recomen the hexagons tho, wihout them, the phone get warmer at heavy use. It needs to be scaled to fit your filament shrinkage and tolerances. Mine was printed at 101%, but should have increased it to 102 or 103 to make it absolutly perfect.

I'm planing on releasing more designs when i get some inspiration. If you have any idea, I'll be happy to check it and maybe implement it.

title: Remix - Geeetech i3 Pro B/C/Aluminum Z Wobble Fix

description.text:
Remix of Geeetech i3 Pro B/C/Aluminum Z Wobble Fix by starbuckbg.

If you print this, please post a picture on the 'I've made one'. Thanks!

After installing my Inductive Auto Level Sensor my prints have not been as good in the Z-axis as the Z axis moves back and forth to 'level' the bed.
I found this posting and gave it a try. I liked that it used the existing hardware. After printing I found that I had to modify it as it did not fit well with my printer, and prints were not any better. When running the Z axis up and down - I could see the X axis moving back and forth.

I used Freecad to copy this item, then modified for the following reasons;

  1. Hard to print as it has many curved edges. I wanted to be able to print flat.
  2. the screw position limited the shoulder length on the bearing support. This also limited the distance the screw could move right and left without bumping into the bearing support and moving it. So I rotated the screw position in order to let the ledge be longer, allowing greater movement for the support.
  3. I needed a thinner support, so I removed some height on the bearing support and the nut retainer part.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro c

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

Lay these flat for printing. I include two versions. One is V3 has some support included. The cylinders break off easily after printing. (use a chisel - be careful and do it away from you!). The other has no support but I was able to get the bearing (nut) installed after slight cleanup.

It works!

The pictures tell it all. The white block is the new and improved z axis printing. The blue section is before I installed the inductive auto level. It was even worse after the auto level. A vast improvement to my eyes.

Special thanks to starbuckbg in posting their solution and getting me started into better prints!

I don't know if anyone else has this problem, but every time I do an improvement to the printer - I have to fix something else. One step forward - two steps back! Part of the fun!!!

Step 1 - Base Layer

Paint your item with a base camouflage color.

Base Camouflage Layer Step 2 - Second Layer

The stencils are thin and can be cut if needed. Use painters tape to protect from overspray. Use the stencil with the larger openings for the secondary base color. Position the stencil over the area to be painted. Spray the second layer.

I used the stencil on the larger flat areas. I used a paint brush and excess paint from the stencil to touch up and cover areas where the stencil could not be used.

Use Painters tape to prevent overspray Secondary Color Layer Step 3 - Third Layer

Use the stencils with the smallest opening for the third layer. Use painters tape to protect areas from over spray. Position stencil and spray paint the third layer.

I used a paint brush and the excess paint on the stencil to touch up and paint areas where the stencil could not be used.

Third layer stencil with painters tape for overspray Third Layer Additional Information

My sensors will be used mostly on trees in the woods. The colors looks to light for my application so I repainted with darker colors.

You can use any colors you wish to match the environment your trying to blend in with. The stencils can be easily cut to a modified pattern during the painting process.

I have included the 123D design files so you can modify the templates for your needs.

author: SSilver2k2

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gmwJKCQtXa1

Welcome to my first posted thing. More to come when I have time to revise designs, and write more of these summaries.

The updated right side piece has been posted, but has not been tested for fitment. If you print it use with caution. I will print it and test it in the next couple days

I designed this upgrade based off of a schematic derived from the I3V12" Prusa CAD file which somebody took the time to import from Colin's laser cutter file. So who ever was responsible for that, thank you for saving me some measuring!

The first time I printed this (and likely the last time for me.) I had to remove material from the posts to make them fit in my frame with a Dremel. Even still I had to press them in pretty hard. To save you some time and elbow grease I removed 0.5mm from each interference to help the tolerance, but you may still have to take away some material with a rotary tool. This happened because I didn't account for the laser cutter kerf from the original design. That said, once installed my Z-axis lead screws have kept much better synchronization than they ever did with the original threaded rod. You might notice I don't have a M3 installed on the right side Z motor mount. That's because I literally had to melt and hammer the plastics together for mine, and the holes were undersized. You should not have to do this as I adjusted the hole size, and the tabs.

Mine is installed on the I3V 10" but I would imagine that it could be installed on many of the Maker Farm kits.

You will need to print four of the side supports, two flanges, and two motor mounts.

Required hardware:

-Lead Screw (This is the one I used - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017AR5QBS/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
400 Zsteps/mm (1/16ths microstepping drivers, and 200 step/rev motors.)

-5mm to 8mm Coupler (Again the one I used - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KHTVOEU/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

Other hardware should work, but this was designed for an 8mm rod with a nut like the one on that threaded rod.

All the other required hardware is re-used from the original brackets.

The only things that are a little less than optimal, the X-axis idler has to be sanded on one side to stay in the retaining hole (this is getting redesigned,) and the belt rubs the back of the left flange a little bit. But, I have had no problems with it. I am planning to design a new carriage to fix the rubbing. The idea was for a front and rear plate to aid rigidity and line up the belt with the center of the rail, has active cooling, illumination, and dual bowden extruders. It will still retain a modular approach for those who don't want a bowden setup. I just want more print speed and less vibration, but I know bowden has it's own drawbacks.

The other modification you will need to make is cutting down the 4 bolts that held the nut for the threaded rod (or just buy new ones.) I just did this by eye, but from measurement the shank of the bolt should be just under 9mm to keep from bottoming into the v-rail.

The brackets press into the X-axis rails. Mine popped in with a little tension, which is where I wanted it. My printer is pretty well calibrated, so pint that part first and make sure it fits in your rails!

Side note, please excuse the messy hot glue on the print cooling fan... Working on updates :P

Printer:

Maker Farm i3v 10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

-I printed in PLA.
-I used 4 perimeters and 4 top layers
-Hexagon infill (check to make sure the side support tabs have infill in them, if they are hollow I recommend adjusting the infill until they are not.)
-Brackets require bridging, or supports, but I recommend bridging if you can.

Uncouple the X axis from the threaded rod. Remove the threaded rod and nuts. Carefully support the X carriage with something and be sure it won't fall (as there is nothing to support the carriage it will just crash into the print bed if it falls, and likely do some damage.) Once you're there unscrew the stepper motors, then the old stepper motor mounts and supports. Next install the new stepper motor mounts and supports. Reinstall the stepper motors using all the same hardware. Install both couplers to the motors' driveshafts.

Remove the X-axis idler and sand down one side (just wait for the redesign), then the old Z-axis brackets from the X-axis rails. Those bolts will need to be shortened to about 8-9mm. Press the new Z-axis mounts into the front of the X-axis rails. These need to be as centered over the stepper motor driveshaft as possible (otherwise you create unnecessary forces which will lead to wear and wobble.) Put one T-nut on top and one on bottom for each side and install the shortened bolts. If they do not thread all the way down, they are not short enough, and the lead screw will not go through it's nut. Take the four M3 nuts and bolts that were originally holding M5 nut in place for the threaded rod and install the new M8 ACME style nuts into the new brackets (2 per side.) The bracket should sit above the nut on the offset side.You can either use them as studs (so that you can lift the X axis off the lead screw nuts,) or you can nut and bolt them in as I did. Once you're here, make sure that the bolts that hold the M8 nuts to the v-rail are just tight enough to allow them to move back and forth (for alignment,) but let the lead screw pass through the nut without effort (don't force anything.) This is so that you can align the lead screw with the coupler and Z-axis v-rail as best as you can. Once you get it all aligned, tighten up those bolts, the X-idler bearing, and anything else that needs to be (I had to take ~2 teeth out of my X-belt.)

comments.text: I really wanted this to work! It's my 3rd attempt at a lead screw upgrade that I don't have to heavily modify. Trying to install on my 10" i3v, I've found that the 12mm M5 screws are bottoming out at the back of the v-slot, not allowing a flush connection for the guide brackets to fit against the v-slot rails (see photo). There just isn't enough depth to the back of the guide brackets. I tried installing with a washer to buy myself some room, but then that gets in the way of the lead screw feeding through.

comments.text: I considered using ball screws for the x and y axis, the trouble here is that most ball screws are not nearly aggressive enough to get the displacement per rotation that these printers need. This means the stepper motor will be running much faster, and they will have less torque. There are high speed ball screws with much more aggressive thread pitches, but they tend to be very cost prohibitive. So for now belts and pulleys are still the way to go for the x and y axis.
comments.author: fovarat

comments.text:
I just installed this on my 8'' i3v and did my first test print, it's awesome! The print quality is like night and day. Using 8mm lead screws is probably the best upgrade for this printer. It's way smoother and quieter, and those threaded rods were just way too prone to getting bent and having backlash in the nuts.
Assembly took a little time with a drill and Dremel to get the holes and tabs sized correctly. I'm hesitant to blame your models though because my printer had some gnarly z-wobble that could have caused things to be so far out of tolerance. But now everything is nice and snug!
I also had to shorten my #10 hardware because it was bottoming out in the aluminum extrusions.

comments.text: You can find the answer to your question I see the "required hardware" header in the description. The lead screws I bought needed 400 steps/mm with 1/16 microstepping on 200 step/rev motors. I have since switched to DRV8825s and am using 1/32 microstepping which means my firmware is set to 800 steps/mm for the z-axis. Hope this helps! If you buy different hardware I can probably still help you figure it out, but the lead screws I bought are still working great.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online. Sure you can go ahead and edit it lol: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kkfA0HCp46g. I have no idea what I was doing. This was my first ever project. I wanted to upgrade my cooling fan and thought that the Wanhao duplicator i3 was the same size as the Monoprice Maker Select v2. Boy was I wrong. I edited the duct I originally wanted, to the Monoprice one and I have to say I am pretty happy with my effort. Apart from some minor issues with the print, I couldn't have asked for a better fit. It fits wonderfully on the Monoprice Maker select V2. I will be editing this soon but feel free to do whatever you want, because I just used Tinkercad, I'm sure there are better programs out there. Also, while searching all over this website I find very few designs for this printer, so here you go, people, who are new like I am and have no idea what they got themselves into. I also believe that the Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 is the same as the Maker Select V2, but I could be wrong please correct me if so. Lastly, leave any comments or suggestions you can think of I would love feedback and better ideas. Thanks and enjoy! (And thanks to Dabeach for the original design)

description.text: This is a tabletop model that resembles PacMan. It may be used just as a decorative item over your table or to put things inside its big mouth :-)

This is the first of two attempts at motorising MishaT's Nautilus gear set. (My second is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:176585) In the past, I have used a rather expensive although very solid, geared DC motor for projects like this but have never had a go at 'hacking' a servo motor to achieve the same thing - low RPM, low voltage and a decent amount of torque. The problem with using a servo motor of course, as well as doing the hacking, is that there is no immediately obvious way of hooking up the drive shaft to turn an axle. This requires some creative thinking which is why this project is still "work in progress" - there will be better ways of coupling the motor to the M3 axle bolt which I have used no doubt so the challenge is on! The motor is run from a standard 1.5V battery as shown in the video. http://youtu.be/HtOLFmOW6Bc It is not quiet so maybe enclosing this thing in a box would be a good idea. (Please excuse the quality of the video - I will turn the radio off next time). The choice of servo by the way was quite arbitrary - it was one of two spares I had in my work box, having used one of a packet of three for an Eggbot derivative over the summer.

Rather than go through a set of instructions, I will provide details of what each of the STL files are for and let you, the creative maker go and get on with it. Saying that, if you have any questions, please leave a comment and I will respond as soon as I can. DisplayPanelNautilus_1
This is a 3mm panel onto which the gears are mounted. It has an odd shaped hole to take the profile of the servo motor which I used, a Turnigy TGY-1800A. The hole is a tight, interference fit on purpose as I did not use any screws (or glue) to hold the motor in place. DisplayStandBaseNautilus_1
Print two of these and slot them onto the display panel above. These are feet to keep the panel upright - or should I say, tilted as the panel sits at an angle of 15 degrees. ServoConnector_Top_1 and ServoConnector_Base_1
These fit together, trapping one of the horns which come with the servo motor. There are three locating pins/holes which might prove tricky to print - I suggest you print these parts alongside others and switch on any cooling fans which you have in order to stop the pins falling over. (I had to clean out the three holes using a 1.5mm drill once the bottom had come off the printer). Glue the two halves together once the horn has been trapped - I don't particularly like using glue and trapping pieces in place but it was difficult (for me) to come up with anything different). Once the servo connector parts have been secured together, The assembly is pushed onto the servo drive and secured using the small screw which comes with the servo motor. An M3 nylon nut is then glued in place into the top ready to accommodate the M3 bolt which forms the drive shaft for one of the gears. NautilusGear_Axle_1
This is a rework of MishaT's original file. You need two of these. Fit M3 screws and washers through each gear each of which have a trapped M3 nut on the other side. One of the gears then screws into the servo coupler and the second through the hole in the display panel onto a washer and M3 nylon nut. The Servo Hack
The principle here is to disconnect the electronics inside the servo motor from its DC motor, remove what is used to limit the movement of the DC motor shaft and then connect wires to the DC motor to power it from a 1.5V battery. Specifics will vary from motor to motor so I suggest and internet search using terms such as "servo motor hack".

description.text:
This is a full sized Hylian Shield I made for my Link cosplay. The body is pieced together with 18 different parts. All of the front pieces are separate so they can be painted before being glued in place. The handles on the back are interchangeable so that this works either left handed or right handed.

The holder is meant to go along with the scabbard so that the shield can hang on your back at an angle like in the game. It is held in place with magnets so that you can take it off while wearing it. If you print the holder, it gets trapped between the two strap loops on the back of the scabbard.

Master Sword
Scabbard

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

The 18 body pieces were glued together with Gorilla Glue. I put blue painters tape along all seams on the front to keep the glue from coming through. Clean the excess glue from the sides and back.

Next, smooth the print out to prepare for painting. You can try XTC-3D, wood filler, spackle, or whatever works for you. Or even try filler primer. Then sand smooth, prime, and paint. After priming, I taped off the sides where it will be chrome and painted the blue. After that was fully dry, I taped off all of the blue and did the chrome. I left the back of the shield with just primer.

For the chrome pieces. first paint them gloss black. Then use Spaz Stix Mirror Chrome.

All of the front pieces were smoothed and painted, then glued in place for the last step. I actually left off the bottom wing pieces and filled the holes in with spackle, but you can use them if you'd like.

The pieces for the handles were glued in place with Gorilla Glue. It is designed to trap nuts inside the pieces that are glued to the shield, and then use screws to hold in the handle. Unfortunately, I can't remember what nuts and bolts I used and I can't find the packages.

I used brown nylon webbing for my forearm on the left side. For the handle, you have 2 options. If you are never going to mount the shield to your back, you can use the "handle.stl" piece. If you want to use magnets, print "handle_with_magnets.stl". I used N50 1/2 x 1/8 inch Neodymium Disc Magnets, 8 on the handle and 8 on the mount. Make sure that you glue them all in the correct orientation.

If you print the holder, you can use small hinges to connect the two pieces. I got them from Lowes, but I can't remember exactly which ones they are.
Designed in 123D Design.

Excellent work. Really nicely modelled, printed and painted.
It's a lot of support cleanup and filling to take care of the joints.

title: Suction Cup replacement for inside-aquarium filter "Eheim pickup"

description.text:
Bothered about the always dropping filter i `ve tried to get rid from the stupid suction cups. Before printing helmets for my fish, i decided to to go this way.
Suction cups get hard with the time or get under layered or rough by algae. Finally you have to buy new ones from time to time. Suction cup producers get rich with this. The solution for me are now Neodymium magnets. Those where you can tow a car with ;)
So i made adapters for the filter and a carriage unit for the magnets outside.
The project is not developed to the finish and may not fit to your filter, but sure an inspiration for your own needs. Previous Thoughts:
I ve chosen the natural PLA because i donÂ´t know if ABS emits hazard parts for the fish. On the other hand i don`t know if PLA gets diluted by the fish tank water on long term. The magnets will rust under water, so i embedded them in silicone. Maybe to print them in closed, or mold them in a resin may be better. At least all materials used inside had to be fish-freindly and not to be hazardous for their environment. Finally the magnet carrier outside is needed to prevent the single magnets smashing together when removing the filter. This could be very painful and hurt your fingers hard. Neodymium magnets are no toys for children!!

I `ve used Neodymium magnets with 15mm diameter and 8 mm height. They can carry 6,5 kg each. The fish tank screen reduces the force but smaller magnets will do it too. Think mine are a bit over sized. While fixing the Filter in the tank you have to take care that the magnets didnÂ´t smash the glass if you leave them drop on it. :( Hold the carrier and let it slowly come.
Anyway, the Eheim pickup is designed to left in the tank and only the filter element is for sliding out the base. The adapters holes for the magnets are slightly bigger than the magnets to have space for a resin.
The holes in the carrier are made to clamp the magnets without glue.
(i know meanwhile that designing a hole and printing it out are two different worlds) While assembling the magnets take care for the polarity of the pairs in the filter and the carrier. I tested it one magnet kept in my fist moving over the other. Take care, the magnets can smash quickly together and shiver or will hurt you badly. Never place the carriage unit directly on the filter, you will not be able to loose it without destroy something. Always test it with a table or other piece of wood in between. Print all parts with pointing the magnet holes at the top. The Adapters from the top and bottom of the filter have different diameters.

comments.text: i am wondering if coating the entire body of the frame in silicone to seal it would cause it to last longer under water?
comments.author: Brainrelates

comments.text: The critical point is to save the magnets from water, the pla itself seems to be water resistant for a couple of years. If you want to coat all I would recommend you to use special aquarium silicone.
comments.author: Brainrelates

comments.text: Any update? I imagine the PLA has dissolved by now...?
comments.author: benmargolin

comments.text:
Oh, sorry I forgot to update. Thanks for asking ;-)
Pla seems to be fine and not visible dissolved yet. On long term use IMHO better than Abs which may adsorb things that fishes make sick.
comments.author: benmargolin

description.text:
Want to adventure as a knight and slay a dragon? How about being a dragon and escaping the cave to go pillage? Or maybe control a cave and kill everyone inside? If you answered yes to any any of these questions, then check out Vast the Crystal Caverns by Leder Games.

The uploaded Thing Files contain everything you need to make the 7 custom meeples for Vast:

  • an stl file to 3D print
  • a pdf file of the artwork to print on sticker paper
  • a studio3 file to cut the stickers out (silhouette portrait file).

Artwork used by permission, created by Kyle Ferrin
kyleferrinart.tumblr.com
https://twitter.com/d20plusmodifier

Vast the Crystal Caverns designed by David Somerville and Patrick Leder, and produced by Leder Games.
http://ledergames.com/

https://youtu.be/wJAqfVaEUcY

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The stl file and pdf of the artwork are scaled to match one another. If you change the scale of one, you need to change the scale of the other.

1 - Ensure the bottoms and sides of the prints are flat by sanding down any build lines or unevenness.

2 - Seal the prints with a primer and paint to final colors (if printed in final colors, skip this step)

2 - Print out the PDF for the artwork on photo sticker paper and cut using an x-acto knife. If you have a Silhouette Portrait, you can use the .studio3 file to cut out the artwork.

3 - Apply stickers to the prints.

I downloaded the artwork from the print and play supplied by Leger Games, and used the Illistrator Live Trace tool to convert it to line work. I then used SolidWorks to extrude the line work into a 3D object.

Check out the video linked above for more details about creating these custom meeples.

title: Hyundai Elantra/Tiburon 5 speed manula transmission shift linkage bushing

description.text:
This is for the 5 speed manual transmission used with the 2.0L inline 4 engines from the mid 2000s. (code named "Beta 2")
They may fit older or newer Hyundai and possibly Kia manual transmissions as well as several of their designes were licensed from Mitsubishi and shared between other models.

Trying to show some love to the Hyundai aftermarket community, which isnt very large for these older Hyundais here in the United States.

These parts are installed on my 2003 Hyundai Accent, into which I swapped the drive-train from a junkyard Elantra. They may fit a stock Accent manual transmission as well, but since I switched from the automatic, I can't say for sure.

These are a replacement for the stock, semi-hollow rubber bushings used and are intended to deliver a more precise, less "mushy" shift due to eliminating slop in the factory bushings. aluminum, brass, and urethane bushings are available for this car for 30-40 USD and I think that's just too much

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

100

Notes:

You will need to print 2 of each file.

I would stick to higher temperature materials as these parts sit under the hood, on top of the transmission of the car, which can get quite hot. I printed mine with Micro Center's Inland brand red ABS

I have used these bushings on several trips so far of various lengths, during the summer and have not seen any evidence of melting, cracking or fatigue. I would advise going with solid infill for safety reasons

light sanding may be needed

if the bushings are a tight fit into the shift cables, sand or Dremel them down in order to fit. this may be particularly necessary if your cables have a bit of rust on them. a tight fit is what you're looking for to deliver precise shifts, so don't go too far. Additionally if they stand too tall when installed, you may need to remove the stock retaining washer which sits below the cotter pin where they mount.

Tinkercad

After measuring the stock rubber bushings with a digital caliper (from harbor freight) I aligned some solid cylinders and another one as a hole. It was quite simple

I designed each bushing in 2 separate pieces so they could be printed with the outer rim to retain the metal shift cable but also not require support material.

comments.text: Printed and installed, (forgot photos, sorry) My old bushings were actually rather worn out, my knob just kinda flopped around. Now it feels nice and solid, works perfectly. Installed on a 2006 Elantra GT with the Beta II engine.
comments.author: swordeater

comments.text: NICE! glad to hear it worked well. My old bushings were pretty fried too. glad to hear someone besides me found some use for them ;)

author: Rochacz21

description.text: This is the second of two attempts at motorising MishaT's Nautilus gear set. In the past, I have used a rather expensive although very solid, geared DC motor for projects like this but have never had a go at 'hacking' a servo motor to achieve the same thing - low RPM, low voltage and a decent amount of torque. The main difference between this motorised gear set and the first one which I made, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:176570 is that here, only one gear moves around - it rotates along with its curved connecting bar around a fixed gear. The problem with using a servo motor of course, as well as doing the hacking, is that there is no immediately obvious way of hooking up the drive shaft to turn an axle. This requires some creative thinking which is why this project is still "work in progress" - there will be better ways of coupling the motor to the M3 axle bolt which I have used no doubt so the challenge is on! The motor is run from a standard 1.5V battery as shown in the video. http://youtu.be/qZQpdfoXxdA It is not quiet so maybe enclosing this thing in a box would be a good idea. (Please excuse the quality of the video - I will turn the radio off next time). The choice of servo by the way was quite arbitrary - it was one of two spares I had in my work box, having used one of a packet of three for an Eggbot derivative over the summer.

As I did in the instructions for my first design, rather than go through a set of instructions, I will provide details of what each of the STL files are for and let you, the creative maker go and get on with it. Saying that, if you have any questions, please leave a comment and I will respond as soon as I can. DisplayPanelNautilus_2
This is a 3mm panel onto which the gears are mounted. It is a triangle shape with a shape cut into the centre to accommodate one of MishaT's Nautilus gears as decoration. The other hole is used for the "working" gears. The fixed gear is held in place by the hexagonal hole - it is up to you how the fixed gear is orientated. DisplayStandBaseNautilus_2
Print two of these and slot them onto the display panel above. These are feet to keep the panel upright - or should I say, tilted as the panel sits at an angle of 15 degrees. They extend backwards to prevent the display panel from falling over - it is top heavy with the servo in place. CurvedConnectorBar_2
This is similar to that used in my rework of MishaT's gear set here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172034 The bar accommodates two hex headed M3 bolts. Take note that once printed, you will need a 3mm drill bit to remove the support material in place in the STL. HexWasher_2
This piece (green in the photographs) takes a standard M3 nut and screws onto the back of the moving gear. Once in place - don't make it too tight - it is locked in place by screwing a second M3 nut above it. I used an M3 'half nut' as the lock nut as I had one to hand, a full M3 nut should work but clearance may be tight. ServoConnector_2
This comes in two parts, both in the STL and need to be glued together once the servo horn has been trapped between them. (It is the horn which pushes onto the servo motor). I am not a great fan of trapping components and holding them in place with glue and I guess that this is the weakest part of this design but it works. I tried holding the pieces together with a piece of heat shrink tubing as you can see in the photographs - it helped keep things together while the superglue did its job but does not provide enough grip on its own. When the two halves are secure, the part of the servo horn which is sticking out needs to be cut off using a craft knife otherwise it will catch on the display panel posts which are used to support the servo motor. NautilusGearFixed_2
This slots into the display panel as described above - no glue needed, it is a tight fit and should not fall out. The M3 bolt which is fixed to the connector bar then passes through this gear and after enough M3 washers to pack the gap, into a nylon M3 nut which is fixed into servo connector. NautilusGear
This is MishaT's original file. You will need two of these - one to rotate (mine is Faberdashery Mercurial Red) and one for decoration (Bling Bling gold in my case). The Servo and its Hack
The servo motor - once 'hacked' is screwed onto the two pillars on the reverse of the display panel. I found a couple of smaller screws than those provided with the servo motor itself although I guess you could drill holes to accommodate those provided if you wish. The principle behind the 'hack' is to disconnect the electronics inside the servo motor from its DC motor, remove what is used to limit the movement of the DC motor shaft and then connect wires to the DC motor to power it from a 1.5V battery. Specifics will vary from motor to motor so I suggest and internet search using terms such as "servo motor hack".

Notes:

I used PLA. Almost any material will work.

Assembly:

The two parts are meant to press together.

  1. Remove existing rope from release lever.
  2. Slide the rope through the hole 'Lock.'
  3. Slide the rope through the release lever.
  4. Slide the rope through the 'Plate.'
  5. Line up the pins on the Lock and Plate with their corresponding holes.
  6. Press the two parts together. You might need a pair of pliers to fully seat the parts.

Rest a little easier knowing you just made it more difficult to someone to rob you.

The Emergency Release is still operable in the case of a power failure or other situation.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed at 90mm/s. Takes two prints for both halves and takes about 2 hours total.

description.text:
This is a simple spool I made for 50g of sample NinjaFlex I got from Printrbot. It prints in two halves that screw together. The inside diameter is 40mm and the outside edge is 94mm. It was designed to fit on the spool holders of my Printrbot Play and Simple. This holds 50g well and could probably go up to 100-150 without any problems. I wouldn't recommend using this with a non-flexible filament since it might make it curl too much.

The holes for the filament are a little tight so the ends can be held in snugly. If you print your first layer too close to the bed, you may close the ends off too much so you may want to scale it up ~5%.

description.text:
I wanted a new lamp for my bedroom that was simple and wall-mounted for easy access. Could have bought one, but where's the fun in that? This one is compact, yet bright enough to light my room just as well as the incandescent lamp I had before did.

This object is super simple to print as well as assemble. In addition to the printed parts, you'll need:

  • LED strip lights, around 2ft (I can't remember the exact length, but I used 13 "sections" of the strip. They come in 5m lengths for like $7 so you should be fine to just get a single roll) -- These are the kind that come on an adhesive-backed strip that can be cut every 3 lights. I went with normal ones but you could get RGB LEDs for some interesting lighting options.
  • Power cord for LED strip lights -- Pretty straightforward, you want your lamp to be able to get power from somewhere (and there isn't much room for batteries inside this thing, though feel free to modify the design to accommodate). Use a power cord designed for LED strip lights. A regular power cord could cause an electrical hazard. Here's the one I used.
  • Switch -- The hole for the switch is designed for a 17mm pusbutton on-off switch I found at my local electronics hobby shop. You could probably find one similar fairly easily or simply open the STL file in your favorite editor and scale the hole/inner supports to fit whatever switch you've got.
  • Wire -- Regular old copper wire for electronics projects. Should be pretty easy to come by.
  • Soldering stuff -- Self explanatory. This is super simple soldering so if you're new to working with electronics this could potentially be a good easy project.
  • Electrical tape -- Should always be on hand for soldering projects. You won't actually need any heat-shrink tubing for this one, but you will want some tape to insulate parts.
  • Hot glue -- For keeping your wiring and whatnot in place
  • Adhesive-backed foam strips -- Often known as Command Strips, they're simple peel-and-stick strips for mounting posters and stuff. I used the small Velcro ones but whatever you have should do.

Ok, and now for the fun part: building it!

  1. Print both the base and lens pieces with their flat sides facing down. Print the lens at 100% infill in a nice transparent material. Print the base however you like. No support for either piece. The custom supports should snap off relatively easily.
  2. Cut your LED strips to length. I designed the lamp to fit 9 sections of the strip around the larger part of the inner mount and 2 sets of 2 sections side-by-side on the front.
  3. Position your strips, peel off the adhesive, and stick into place. Make sure they're nice and firm. Sticking them into place beforehand really helps keep everything in place for soldering.
  4. Wire it up. I had a whole detailed explanation here of how exactly to wire this thing but I realized it was starting to become a bit long-winded and probably less helpful than it should be. This is an ultra simple circuit. There's a diagram above for reference. All you need to do is connect one positive (+) lead from each LED strip together and one negative (-) lead from each LED strip together so you have a single (-) wire and a single (+) wire. I found the easiest way to do this is to connect one (-) lead from the long strip to the (-) lead on one of the front strips and the (+) lead from the long strip to the (+) lead on the other front strip, then connect both leads on the other ends of the front strips with short wires (see picture) to complete that part of the circuit. Then I stripped off a bit of the middle of both wires, soldered on some extra lengths of wire to go to the switch, and insulated them with electrical tape so they didn't interfere with each other. Then you simply connect one of the wires to the switch, the other to one of the wires from the power cable, and then the other power cable wire to the remaining section of switch.
  5. Keep it together. Hot glue is great for keeping all of the wires in place, and the added benefit is that if you use too much you can simply run a razor blade at a low angle along the back surface to trim the glue flush.
  6. Pop the front lens in place. For me it snaps in nicely with a bit of pressure.
  7. Mount it to your wall with the adhesive strips, plug it in, and enjoy!

description.text:
I created this to mount the stinger end of a Harbor Freight (HF) Plasma Cutter on a CNC Plasma Cutting table. The attachment holes and slots are designed to fit 8020 aluminum extrusion 10 series (1"x3") which is what I am using for the bottom of my Z axis.   
The plasma cutter handle snaps in and then can be  secured with a zip tie.   
Future version may have an overcenter clip integrated to eliminate the zip tie.

Single piece, just upload and print. I used 3mm ABS and .35 layers with no support. I had no issues with deformations during print, although there is a lot of surface area on the base layer so it can bee difficult to lift the finished print off the print bed if you use hairspray to prevent lifting.
